required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Performing Fractional Flow Reserve Without Anticoagulation During Diagnostic Catheterization
clinical_study.official_title: Retrospective Assessment of the Safety of Performing Fractional Flow Reserve (FFR) of the Myocardium Without Anticoagulation During Diagnostic Cardiac Catheterization

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the safety of performing fractional flow reserve (FFR) of the myocardium without using anticoagulation by performing a retrospective review of 100 consecutive patients who have undergone this procedure during diagnostic catheterization.

detailed_description.textblock: An experienced interventional cardiologist can perform FFR in a brief period of time. This procedure can safely be performed without anticoagulation, thereby lowering the associated procedural risks by avoiding the bleeding and groin complications that may occur with anticoagulation. Performing FFR without anticoagulation may also decrease facility costs as femoral artery closure can be performed using standard protocols for a diagnostic procedure, instead of standard protocols for an interventional procedure when a patient has been anticoagulated. Performing FFR without anticoagulation does not increase risk of injury to the coronary artery or thrombus in the coronary artery.

primary_outcome.measure: Complications related to use of pressure wire

arm_group.description: Patients with suspected coronary artery disease undergoing FFR to assess physiological significance of stenosis

intervention.description: Fractional Flow Reserve performed without anticoagulation

study_pop.textblock: Patients who underwent fractional flow reserve (FFR) by Dr. Jonathan Roberts without anticoagulation during diagnostic catheterization were included in this registry.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with moderate stenosis who underwent FFR without anticoagulation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Therapeutic anticoagulation
